snippet.title: CFA brigades failing to meet benchmark response times, chief officer says
snippet.content:
Related Story:
CFA brigades are failing to meet benchmark response times in urban areas demonstrating a need for reform, chief officer Steve Warrington has declared. Ahead of the release of a parliamentary inquiry report into Premier Daniel Andrews' fire service reforms, data has been posted detailing fire response times in urban areas. The CFA has set a benchmark of 90 per cent of calls in built-up areas be responded to in eight minutes. But the data shows brigades are only meeting the eight-minute mark 80 per cent of the time. The numbers are worse when volunteer only brigades are considered, with only 61 per cent of volunteer brigades in greater metropolitan areas meeting the benchmark. Mr Warrington said, in an email to the CFA, the data showed the need to improve. "Let me be clear, the response time data does underscore where greater flexibility in our sector would provide a capacity to improve service delivery,'' Mr Warrington said. "Across the board, our people provide a world-class firefighting service, but it is clear there are some limitations within our current system." It is the first time the data has been published in this form. A parliamentary inquiry is examining laws from the Government that would abolish the Metropolitan Fire Brigade (MFB) and replace it with a new urban fire rescue Victoria (FRV). Under the plan the
